content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Experience: Played this in closed beta, and open beta, pre-order, pay to play for a month and got tired of poor world pvp mechanics and quit. It went free to play and I tried it out again much later and it was fun for kicking around in PvE and I leveled a few more toons to the cap level of 30. I have 3 level 30 Villains and 3 level 30 Heroes.PvE: The grind to get into raiding is more than I have ever seen in an MMO and I have played a lot of them. Game mechanics for raids are very poor. You expect to be leveling a very active controller character and end up standing around with your thumb up your butt just handing out energy to the tanks and healer. The one big raiding guild that I had joined was full of "lifers" (people who had purchased a lifetime subscription to the game) and they added their own drama to the game to spice it up... I was banned for being "a potential spy"... PvP: The PvP mechanics in the arenas are evolutionary, however severely unbalanced even more than other MMOs. Open World PvP is similar mechanics where there is a mirror world where everyone can PvP no matter your level. Level 30s often squish low level players for kicks.Social: The game keeps coming out with new paid expansions, however the population continues to dwindle. I still have the game installed because I like the PvE fighting mechanics. It's fun to watch some of the combos and devastation in your wake. Hardly anyone reads the chat, and its near imposable to get into an active guild because most of them are dead. Opinion: It's fun to tool around with a buddy, just don't expect to be able to play with your friends right away. The introduction to the game is roughly 15-30 mins long depending on your experience with the game. I still keep it installed just to pop in from time to time and beat down some mobs.

Posted: November 1, 2012
												Marvel Comics "DC Universe" is a simulation title, which allows the player to pretend to be a little girl, pretending to be a super hero, or villian.  You will spend several hours selecting combination of tights and capes which are not as inhumanly offensive to the eye possible, and then mash the "1" through "4" keys repetedly untill completion.  The game ends when players collect all of the missing pages of the Necronomicon, and return the missing $20 to Slenderman.  There is a twist ending, where the players and Christopher Walken go to Denny's, but it's only achievable by using Canadian currency in the slenderman scenario.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												I believe this is a highly underrated game. While I haven't played in years, I know you can not pay a dime, while not being able to play any endgame, there is much fun to be had.For me, I mostly enjoyed my knowledge of heroes and villains in the DC universe increasing 100 fold.  From the big ones to the small, there are so many encounters, either talking or fighting to be had.It's beat to approach this not as mmo, but an rpg.  Bring a friend or 3 and do the many 4 man instances or 2 man ones.  Even alone groups can be found and there is much lore to dive into.You get many customization options from powers to weapons.  So any power can be combined with any weapons giving you so many choices of specs. While your power stays the same, weapons can be changed very often.The minimal abilities is great as well. Most mmos give you 2 to 3 dozen buttons to push, where you have about 7 here.If you're a super hero, comic, or DC fan you have nothing to lose by checking out this free game.If you're looking for an mmo to dive into hardcore, you need to spend money and you're probably better off playing a newer mmo.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												DC Universe is one of the best games I ever played. I got addicted to it real quick. It's easy to learn but hard to master. Progression is 1-30 then T1-T6. 1-30 takes you a day and I mean an ENTIRE day if you spend the WHOLE day grinding non-stop. If you're a working man who only has a couple of hours each day, it'll take you a week. With a party it's a lot faster. You have to join a league or else you'll get nowhere in this game. Please don't PUG too much. Plan instances with your league. You'll get♥♥♥♥♥♥done much faster that way. You have to get membership after level 30 because you won't be able to progress without it as you lack all the DLC's. And last thing, if you only have two hours a day to play this game, then this game is not for you. I'm saying that because you wouldn't be getting the full experience, only a sample. Yes, it's P2W but it's worth it. I highly recommend this game.

												Was a good game, the PVP was great. Servers got hacked but everybody was compensated with Batman style masks etc..  Then for European players like myself, i was moved to ProSeiben (spell) servers. Took 2 weeks to get my characters back. My Batman mask was gone and "there was nothing they could do"  about that. I had to change my log in name to start playing again.All set up again after the server move, i start playing again, i create 16 new characters, i am still a little sore about not getting my batman mask after my personal details were hacked but i continued on. THen i get an email that i am being moved server again. After a 2 hour rigmarole i managed to change server. But not until i change my Username again !!  I change server and everything seems a little quiet. 6 months later i am yet to see a bad guy on the server. So i can no longer play. Time and money invested in this game wasted. Just feel messed about by them at this stage.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2013
												This is a really fun game.  It kept me entertained for several hours, the missions, side quests, challenges are all fun!  Also I liked how they let you customize your character. You can choose to be a hero or a villian.  I choose villian to have the Joker as my mentor.  Also it's awesome that it's free, but you have to pay for DLC.  The one downside is that when you start out you are just getting into the game and really high level enemies come to kill the low level players.  That really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off but I got used to it.  So if you want to try out the game it's free.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I don't think I've spent more time in any other MMO. I've played Star Wars Galaxies, Lord of the Rings Online, The Old Republic, Dungeons and Dragons Online, Aion: Ascension, Runes of Magic, and a few others and haven't like an MMO as much as I like DCUO. Its extremely cool and satisfying to control every aspect of your hero, like whether they fly or have super-speed, control ice or fire or time itself, and each and every piece of their outfit. The voices are actually well-done in this, featuring Adam Baldwin, Mark Hamill, Wil Wheaton, and Gina Torres, among others. Try this out; I mean, seriously, ITS FREE.

content:
Posted: March 23
												I've played several superhero mmorpgs and this is the best.  That doesn't mean its all good.Pros:-Great costume choices and customization-Great link ins to the great DC franchise (God knows we aren't getting it in the current DC movies) !!!!!!!!-Still high population-F2P-Good CommunityCons:-End game is terrible: you will repeat the same instances over and over and over and over....oh and they are time locked or pay (and this is true even if you are a subscriber...wtf)-Subscribing is near uselss don't waste your money-All powers while they look different really aren't...and you will hit the same combos over and over and over-There is like 2 builds for a power that are acceptable in the endgame...if you don't do them you are useless-End game makes you feel useless and weak anyhowI've thought about booting this up a couple times lately...started the updater then about 5 minutes in realize how much the end really turned me away from the game.  Each time I stop the updater and I don't regret it.  I am of the mind that if its something in the beginning that bugs you about an mmorpg, grind through it for the good stuff, but if its at the end then whats the point of playing on?  I did love this game and had a blast playing it with some great people but I can't see myself booting it up again.

content:
Posted: March 23
												When you start it, it's ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. The customization is great, the free roam is really amazing, with fun huge maps. Not only that but the super powers make the free roam MUCH better (flying, parkour/climb, and super speed). This game is great! I played it for a long time, but the problem with it is that it sucks when you get high level, it just becomes mostly grind "x" amount of enemies at this location, and then you get less boss fights (which are fun af). This review is written from memory and I don't know if they changed anything. I HIGHLY SUGGEST YOU START THOUGH, just to get hooked. Note there is DLC and an ingmae currency for some powers and wicked armour but see that's not that important unless you wanna be OP. I was never so invested that I'd visit forums or see what devs are doing (I was younger so I wasn't following updates). tl;dr just play it and see if you like the late game experience. Starts great though!

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												I had my fun, but now, it seems like DCUO wants people to stay at the same level for ever and ever.First, you needed to pass tremendous amount of time to get marks of triumph to be able to buy gear.Now, they have marks of victory that you simply cannot get by farming lower levels. The only way is to pay to unlock higher levels. Which is kinda fair, I don't mind paying for a game, but it destroys every possibility of cooperating with players with a lower level. Why would I waste my time farming levels that give useless stuff? Why can't I enjoy the stages I bought earlier anymore?This game had a great potential, I love feeling the powers of being a green lantern, but I feel like I cannot progress anymore. Maybe I'm doing something wrong, but this game lost its magic because of greed.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
												When I first played this game (quite some time ago) it was kinda meh. Didn't really have any reason to keep playing, story was meh, my character felt meh, just MEH.YEARS later. Played with some guys from my clan, got some run through and explanation of the current game. It was fine, but everything was still pretty "meh." I don't know if I have some kind of DC bias that's making me so meh, but meh. If you are into MMO's it's fine, and the system of subscription is SUPER fair (especially if you play other daybreak games), but honestly, I got tired of this game even faster than I did the first time around. TL;DRIf you like action MMO's and have a good connection speed, give it a shot, you might love it. For this old man, however, it really doesn't offer anything special at all, and is underwhelming in general.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												DC Universe Online misses the mark for me.It has some awesome artwork cutscenes and recognisable voice actors (like Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill) but for me that's where the excitement kinda ends.The cities themselves are lifeless. I mean, there are bad guys all around, but there are no real people. And with all the other players around with their superpowers, I didn't feel like a super hero/villain. I think that's just a flaw with the concept. You can't have everyone running around with powers in a city that's void of life and feel important to the world you're in.But if you enjoy the DC comics you might find some joy in being around familiar characters/locations. Even though I enjoy DC, I personally didn't.But hey! It's free-to-play so it won't cost you.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												This game is fun for about 15 minutes. Based heavily on the gameplay and engine from the Justice League games on console this game offers prettier graphics but very little depth. There really isn't a consistent story to pull a player in. You can choose a mentor which sets you up with a loose storyline to follow but is bisected, quadrasected, basically chopped to bits by other intersecting mini stories. And that's a large part of the problem. There isn't any reason to KEEP playing the game besides leveling up and getting better items. But to what end? To play the same mini stories and complete the same redundant tasks. Don't get me wrong I am not saying the game is all bad. What I am saying is that if DCU was a food it would taste like carboard. Considering the age of the game and the lack of changes and updates made over the YEARS it has existed it's pretty obvious there aren't many plans for improving the game at all. The powers you get to choose from are quite limited and become pretty bland when so many other players have the exact same powers you do. The ability to create a unique hero or villain is extremely limited. I would recommend this game as again a least of the terrible games Steam offers. Be prepared to hit a ceiling unless you want to pay for membership though because this is definitely a money game. And if I am going to spend money on a game it damn sure won't be this one. Play it for free, have a little fun, and get rid of it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												Oh man, I should know better than to review an MMO.  I've been playing on and off since Beta how many years ago.  The BIGGEST problem now is the community is very toxic.   The game just has that feeling of an MMO on its way out and the company is just rushing to squeeze whatever money they can before that happens.  The game itself feels like a lot of wasted potential, because it really should have been great.Free to Play. Your Way.  Should be grounds for a lawsuit, because in actuality, you'll have a hard time getting through the base content without putting in $5 to get bumped up to preferred status or whatever it's called these days.  $5 isn't bad deal but then you'll quickly realize that you can't get mid tier gear because of the cost restrictions so you'll have to either pay the sub, stay where you are, or pay to get an escrow unlock.  You're better off paying for the sub.This game is a grind, once you hit max level, 30, which can be done in a week without much effort if you're close to semi-hardcore.  Up to 3 weeks if you're pretty casual.  Once you hit level 30, grats because its all farming content for a tier gear upgrade.  Which isn't all bad, but its not varied enough, the contact packs are all pretty small and once you get past the lower level ones, there isn't much incentive to go back and do them so it becomes content that you paid for, but you've stopped using.

												Better than I thought it would be. We all know that hero games are ht and miss always have been. This one a hit.  Game play is console oriented in controls, button mashing combos. The style is like most MMos, amument park style. In the US there is only 2 servers left. PC and PS3. The Game ask if you want to play PvP or PvE, its the same sever your just  flagged for PvP or not. You can change that at any time.Prices, They are not bad , in some ways beat Planetside 2 The PC server comunity is stand offish at best. I've been in 3 Guilds, and no one is helpful at all, and I'm still looking for the right league. I might go Membership, if i could find the right guys to hang with  but at this rate that looking like a no go.The games only 2 years old. I'm afraid it will die in part to the comunty on the server.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												I have mixed thoughts about this game. For starters it is fun you get to customize your character, get to equip him or her with cool gear, make him/her a hero or villian, pick a mentor, and fight along sides heroes or villians. But here are the downsides there are only 3 mentors per side, you don't get to pick which her or villian to fight with, not enough customizations, not alot of weapons or powers, even if you have superspeed or flight you go really slow, members get anything making it to win you need membership, you don't get to choose your missions, you can't be a hero or villian in the regular roam about world, and you can't talk back to the characters in the game like you can do in Star Wars The Old Republic or Star Trek Online. Overall I found this game to be good. I really do I have 124 hours on it and I still play it but if you don't want to spend money on this game then don't get it because you have to spend money to make it fun. If you want a free game that is fun I would suggest getting Star Wars The Old Republic because you get to choose your destiny with over 8 different story modes with your classes.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												This game is fun for about 15 minutes. Based heavily on the gameplay and engine from the Justice League games on console this game offers prettier graphics but very little depth. There really isn't a consistent story to pull a player in. You can choose a mentor which sets you up with a loose storyline to follow but is bisected, quadrasected, basically chopped to bits by other intersecting mini stories. And that's a large part of the problem. There isn't any reason to KEEP playing the game besides leveling up and getting better items. But to what end? To play the same mini stories and complete the same redundant tasks. Don't get me wrong I am not saying the game is all bad. What I am saying is that if DCU was a food it would taste like carboard. Considering the age of the game and the lack of changes and updates made over the YEARS it has existed it's pretty obvious there aren't many plans for improving the game at all. The powers you get to choose from are quite limited and become pretty bland when so many other players have the exact same powers you do. The ability to create a unique hero or villain is extremely limited. I would recommend this game as again a least of the terrible games Steam offers. Be prepared to hit a ceiling unless you want to pay for membership though because this is definitely a money game. And if I am going to spend money on a game it damn sure won't be this one. Play it for free, have a little fun, and get rid of it.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												I had my fun, but now, it seems like DCUO wants people to stay at the same level for ever and ever.First, you needed to pass tremendous amount of time to get marks of triumph to be able to buy gear.Now, they have marks of victory that you simply cannot get by farming lower levels. The only way is to pay to unlock higher levels. Which is kinda fair, I don't mind paying for a game, but it destroys every possibility of cooperating with players with a lower level. Why would I waste my time farming levels that give useless stuff? Why can't I enjoy the stages I bought earlier anymore?This game had a great potential, I love feeling the powers of being a green lantern, but I feel like I cannot progress anymore. Maybe I'm doing something wrong, but this game lost its magic because of greed.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												I have mixed thoughts about this game. For starters it is fun you get to customize your character, get to equip him or her with cool gear, make him/her a hero or villian, pick a mentor, and fight along sides heroes or villians. But here are the downsides there are only 3 mentors per side, you don't get to pick which her or villian to fight with, not enough customizations, not alot of weapons or powers, even if you have superspeed or flight you go really slow, members get anything making it to win you need membership, you don't get to choose your missions, you can't be a hero or villian in the regular roam about world, and you can't talk back to the characters in the game like you can do in Star Wars The Old Republic or Star Trek Online. Overall I found this game to be good. I really do I have 124 hours on it and I still play it but if you don't want to spend money on this game then don't get it because you have to spend money to make it fun. If you want a free game that is fun I would suggest getting Star Wars The Old Republic because you get to choose your destiny with over 8 different story modes with your classes.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I don't think I've spent more time in any other MMO. I've played Star Wars Galaxies, Lord of the Rings Online, The Old Republic, Dungeons and Dragons Online, Aion: Ascension, Runes of Magic, and a few others and haven't like an MMO as much as I like DCUO. Its extremely cool and satisfying to control every aspect of your hero, like whether they fly or have super-speed, control ice or fire or time itself, and each and every piece of their outfit. The voices are actually well-done in this, featuring Adam Baldwin, Mark Hamill, Wil Wheaton, and Gina Torres, among others. Try this out; I mean, seriously, ITS FREE.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												Oh man, I should know better than to review an MMO.  I've been playing on and off since Beta how many years ago.  The BIGGEST problem now is the community is very toxic.   The game just has that feeling of an MMO on its way out and the company is just rushing to squeeze whatever money they can before that happens.  The game itself feels like a lot of wasted potential, because it really should have been great.Free to Play. Your Way.  Should be grounds for a lawsuit, because in actuality, you'll have a hard time getting through the base content without putting in $5 to get bumped up to preferred status or whatever it's called these days.  $5 isn't bad deal but then you'll quickly realize that you can't get mid tier gear because of the cost restrictions so you'll have to either pay the sub, stay where you are, or pay to get an escrow unlock.  You're better off paying for the sub.This game is a grind, once you hit max level, 30, which can be done in a week without much effort if you're close to semi-hardcore.  Up to 3 weeks if you're pretty casual.  Once you hit level 30, grats because its all farming content for a tier gear upgrade.  Which isn't all bad, but its not varied enough, the contact packs are all pretty small and once you get past the lower level ones, there isn't much incentive to go back and do them so it becomes content that you paid for, but you've stopped using.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												DC Universe Online misses the mark for me.It has some awesome artwork cutscenes and recognisable voice actors (like Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill) but for me that's where the excitement kinda ends.The cities themselves are lifeless. I mean, there are bad guys all around, but there are no real people. And with all the other players around with their superpowers, I didn't feel like a super hero/villain. I think that's just a flaw with the concept. You can't have everyone running around with powers in a city that's void of life and feel important to the world you're in.But if you enjoy the DC comics you might find some joy in being around familiar characters/locations. Even though I enjoy DC, I personally didn't.But hey! It's free-to-play so it won't cost you.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												I've read alot of reviews claiming that dcuo's free to play model is false advertising but this couldn't be further from the truth.The amount of time it would take you to complete all the free content could range anywhere from 40 hours to hundereds depending on whether or not you go for all the feats or just rush through the content. When dcuo was released it was a $60 release that sold very well, held a strong playerbase for many years and went free to play to offer players a way to experience the game without having to invest to see if they would like it first.but as all free to play games will, dcuo has its ways of genereting a profit to pay it's dev team, this is broken down into episodes you can purchase that act as dlc's. none of these effect the base game. all orignial content as well as the first two dlcs are completely free. may even be more but i have paid to have a membership since the switch to f2p so i can't say exactly how many dlc's are part of the free package.The only valid argument about how bad the f2p model is comes from the fact that they do limit the mount of ingame cash you can carry on your character as a free member. this is annoying but not hindering to progression, since anything you would buy with in game cash is purely cosmetic aside from gear mods which you don't need until you get into the dlc's anyways.Now.......to the review.i've played thousands upon thousands of games in my life time, none of which can hold a candle to dcuo. when i tried to get my fiance to play it she thought it was boring the first few hours. fast forward three years and she's clocked over a thousand hours and wont play anything else.the exact same thing happend to my buddy when i showed it to him, he wasn't sure about it the first couple days, now dcuo is his all time favorite game. also putting in over a thousand hours.For an mmo the combat is fast and fun. the movement is in the vien of games like protoype and infamous where you can fly, freerun, or zip around at lighting speeds like the flash. each power is unique and requires a different mind set while using them, content pacing is good and story development is colorful and fully voice acted from the tutorial to the latest dlc. only reading you have to do is when your choosing your skills/powers.PVP shines in dcuo, though buggy at times it plays more like a arcade fighter then your typical mmo. Where blocking at the right times and following up with a hard hitting combo will reign supreme over following a predetemed skill rotation.character customization is better here then any game i've played. your "styles" are choosen and edited seperately from your gear. so you never have to choose between looking the way you want and being geared with the right equipment. in this case you can have your cake and eat it too. this leads to a ton of inspired characters, leading to many nights that had me and my friends flying around for hours just checking out everyones characters.as far as end game content goes, its never a dull moment. the content will bring you defeat if your not paying attention, but it never means more then respawning and trying the fight over again. with each tier of gear you get drastically stronger and it gives the vibes of something quite similar to reaching that next level of super sayian if you where goku. I stopped playing for about six months due to the fact that update 47♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥a few people off and the player base got a bit smaller, but since my return there are as many people as ever and in a weeks time they are merging the pc and playstation servers with crossplay functionality which will triple the playerbase for those of use that play on pc. this is not an exageration the playstion playerbase is huge.I could go one and on about my love for this game but i'll let this tome of a review and my playtime speak for what I havent already said.would I recommend this game? does a bear $*** in the woods?but don't take my word for it, tho not free in its complete form its free to try, so give it a go.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												This has been a ton of fun for casual play. In past MMOs I've played, the two biggest pet peeves I've had is lack of character customization and mobility at lower levels of play. As a casual player, I don't usually find myself playing at the higher levels where the cooler-looking gear and mobility options are found in other MMOs, DC Universe Online takes a different approach. Character creation, from the onset, gives you a wealth of starting looks, powers, and tweaks to choose from to make a variety of unique-feeling characters. Medieval barbarian with fire magic? Go for it. Futuristic flying robot with machine pistols? You can do that to. You even have some choices with different idle and movement animations, which helps even more with making your character feel distinct.Character movement is also a blat from the game's start. There are no mounts in this game. Instead, you choose from one of a few movement capabilities  such as Flight, Super Speed, and Acrobatics. All of these make transit between quests as much fun as any other part of the game. I personally love using Acrobatics to scale tall buildings, leap from them, glide across the skies of Gotham, and land with a ground-shattering smash at my quest destination. I've never played an MMO where going from point A to point B was so much fun it itself. Another aspect I enjoyed was the integration of DC comic characters in most of the quests you undertake. I have a passing familiarity with the DC roster from days watching the Justice League/Justice League Unlimted cartoons, so seeing various heroes pop up at the end of a quest for my villain character to immolate and punch in the face provides a lot of entertainment value for me. There's a lot of voice-acting done here, including the iconic performances of Mark Hamil as the Joker and Kevin Conroy as Batman. The game is definitely not perfect. Much of the content is behind paywalls, and Daybreak will not hesitate to remind you of this every step of the way; however, I've been able to experience much of the game without paying a penny. The combat is so-so. There are some cool combos and tricks, but a lot of it revolves around chaining together "stun lock" loops. They're satisfying to pull off at times, but the game comes to a standstill when a swarm of NPCs are doing the same to you all in unison. Overall, I'd recommend this for folks who want a fun casual MMO experience where they can create all sorts of goofy characters and have them run around the world of DC comics.

												I have mixed thoughts about this game. For starters it is fun you get to customize your character, get to equip him or her with cool gear, make him/her a hero or villian, pick a mentor, and fight along sides heroes or villians. But here are the downsides there are only 3 mentors per side, you don't get to pick which her or villian to fight with, not enough customizations, not alot of weapons or powers, even if you have superspeed or flight you go really slow, members get anything making it to win you need membership, you don't get to choose your missions, you can't be a hero or villian in the regular roam about world, and you can't talk back to the characters in the game like you can do in Star Wars The Old Republic or Star Trek Online. Overall I found this game to be good. I really do I have 124 hours on it and I still play it but if you don't want to spend money on this game then don't get it because you have to spend money to make it fun. If you want a free game that is fun I would suggest getting Star Wars The Old Republic because you get to choose your destiny with over 8 different story modes with your classes.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												I'm going to preface this review by admitting first that it is very difficult for me to get into an MMO in general.  I spent what I feel are too many hours on World of WarCraft only because I had friends who played, but I can't help but feel it just got worse as it became more casual with every new update.  For someone like me to get into an MMO, it has to have a good story that is being played through, and it can't just be repetative if it is not challenging, and the only MMOs I can say I've ever liked are both action MMOs, Star Trek Online and Defiance.  Yes, they can also be repetative, but they are challenging, fast-paced, and require plenty of changes in strategy for different situations, all the while having very engaging stories.  I love the idea of getting immersed in fantasy MMOs too, but as I get older and continue to take on more real-life responsibilities, they are simply too slow-paced, and ironically, the ones I liked the best, like LOTRO and Conan, seem to be the least popular, and I feel as though all of them go quickly to crap as soon as they become free-to-play and pay-to-win.  And lastly, I don't feel as though I should be forced to waste time levelling just because all of the fun things to do in any particular MMO are all 'end-game'.That said, just take my review for what it is, one person's opinion who this game might simply not be for.  For starters, DC Universe does have a tremendous amount of customization options for the creation of one's character.  The problem is that it feels like it pretty much ends there, because no matter what sort of character you create, they all play the same.  You have your melee attack, your ranged attack, and effects that you can add to them, which are also mostly the same between character types.  The action is certainly fast, but highly repetative and not at all challenging.  You'll actually have to try, or have something like a controller malfunction happen, to die.  Like most MMOs, all quests are go here, fetch this/beat up this person/these people, and then go back to turn it in.  Worse, I absolutely hate collectibles.  The slow down the action to search for and all you have to do is find a map online to locate them, and the rewards aren't worth a damn.  The controllers are horrible when climbing if you choose Acrobatics or Speed-type movements; too often you get stuck on any small outcropping of buildings as the directional controls change and your character spazzes out.  And the stories are boring as hell because, as somewhat mentioned before, all story quests invlove going to a place, beating up baddies, beating up the supervillain, rinse, repeat.  And this game has one of the worst PVP systems I'd ever seen.  There is literally no level matching, so you never know going into a PVP match whether your level 12 Character is going up against a level 30 opponent and vice versa.  You'd have to be a pretty big DC fan to be able to keep going after all of this.  The last straw for me was when I discovered that, at times, a free player must wait in a long queue while Members and Premium players login almost immediately.  That is just ridiculous.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												I played DCUO from the very start and took a break.  I recently came back to this game and was pretty much disappointed that I couldn't access my old characters (thanks daybreak!) unless I paid money to get my "deleted" (aka old characters that I never deleted) back. After that, I decided to uninstall.Other than the shady practice, the game is still fun when leveling up, endgame is a pretty tedious grind tbh. Basic powers you start off with are good(fire and ice being near top dps), but if you want more powers you'll have to cough up money, as expected. Biggest question: Can this game keep you for the long run?Nope. For a month or two, sure. I can't see myself playing this again for more than a month.

												I mainly speak from a nostalgic point of view, I don't have many hours, but I played this game loads on Playstation 3. content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												For a free game, it's very entertaining, and certainly worth trying if you are okay with making a separate account. The customization is impressive, graphics detailed, and performance generally good. Many parts of this game make it unique, but still has the classic MMORPG theme to it, making players of that genre already familiar with the gameplay. My complaints are that, while the game is certainly not Pay-To-Win, every indent and corner seems to have a slot for accepting money. They have implemented almost every form of premium goodies I can think of. This includes crates, skins, furniture, items, and equipment. There's even a cap to the amount of money you can have on hand, and you need to pay real money to access the extra. I do agree that the developers have put an astonishing amount of work and detail into the game, and the company should receive payment for it's work, but the game almost begs for it. If you can ignore the features added solely for sinking money, then I would definitely recommend giving this a go.Oh, and the Bee-themed enemies are super annoying.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												EDIT: According to another player you can restore your old characters for free, so ignore that.I'm trying to figure out what made me redownload this game, but for the life of me I cannot comprehend what was going through my head.I'll try to be fair and start off this review with things I like about the game.1.Voice acting.The game is almost fully voice acted, and it is done rather well.Some classic voice actors are in this cast, such as mark hamill as the joker, The cutscenes are really nice too, animatic comic shorts with fun dialog.2.CombatThe combat, whilst simplistic at it's core with a rock papper scissors theme with blocking ranged and melee, is rather fun.There are many abilities many weapons and a good ammount of combo's making this feel like a nice action beat uhm up.3.Visually appealing sceneryThe graphics look nice, not 100% modern anymore, but still polished with a few different areas with unique feels between gotham and metropolis.4.Let's you be a hero OR villian.A lot of games now a days have this "nothing is black and white" mentality when it comes to factions.There are usually multiple factions and no one is set in a better light than the other.But in this game you can be outright evil if you want to. (though sadly there is no middle ground or multiple choices, you're either a criminal or a hero)Now onto the reasons why this game is a failure, has failed, and will hopefully shut down.1.Free to play, expensive to enjoy.This game will attempt to squeeze every penny out of you if you let it.Not only are almost half of the power types behind a paywall, there are even basic in game features most mmo games don't even consider making you pay real life money for caged off behind pay walls.One of the worst offenders of this is money in game.That's right, the money you pick up off the ground in game has a limit.1,500$ of in game currency is all you can pick up.If you pick up any more of that without spending it...well, that money is gone now.You can't use it, you can't get to it, but you can look at it taunting you all day just begging you to spend real life cash to get to it.Not a problem you think to yourself, I'll just pay the price of unlocking infinite money an- NO! WRONG!It is a monthly cost to increase your money limit.And it comes in levels.First level?2.5k currency Second,Infinite.So there are two layers of paywalls just to get infinite cash, to use the money you earned to buy things.It's either that or buy tokens to unlock some of the money just once.There are also entire episodes (raids/areas) hidden behind 5 dollar pay walls as well.Just scroll up from this and go look at how much it costs to unlock all of the DLC of this game.Now add up that along with a 15 dollar per month charge just to 'fully' enjoy the game.Fun right?2.Monthly charge option in a F2P game.This is probably the dumbest thing any of these games can do.There is a reason your game couldn't keep using a monthly fee model and survive.It's an outdated archiac payment model.I would almost gladly pay 30 bucks for this game if they removed the money cap and monthly pay option, and just made the things you can buy vanity items.That's how almost 100% of the successful F2P games do it.This game is doomed to shut down just from that, at least till some of the die hard fans start losing their nerve as well.3. Limited to two character slots in F2P.I don't know about you, but a game all about making a unique character should allow you to toy around with more than 2 options.I usually use my second slot for test characters, but everytime I made it to level 10 on one of them, I ended up deleting them because I knew it would be permanent and I couldn't try out any other combinations.So be absolutely sure what you have it what you want, because if you have two characters you don't like, one has to be deleted to make another.4.Huge gear gap.This game has a severe gear gap between new and old school players, and the only way to really fix the gap is to buy some of the newer raids to keep up with the new gear sets.Even tokens in game for buying gear have a currency cap as well, so you will constantly need to go back and forth buying single pieces of gear, going back out and grinding more money, just constantly refreshing your money.I took to buying expensive vendor items and reselling them as currency, which is an painful way to work around the issue of the money cap.I spent a long time trying to grind pvp and money to finally buy a full set of epics in the game.I thought I was pretty well geared, everything I had was a massive upgrade from the blues I had.But along came a plasma glowing shield wielding man, covered head to toe in cash shop effects and a money blocked weapon set.I spent 15 minutes blocking all of his heavy attacks, smashing his ranged attacks, and breaking through his blocks.After all that time I still did no damage to him, and frustrated that he couldn't kill me, he finally just slowly flew away anticlimactically after giving up.There are no words for how depressing that is, to totally outclass someone, but be unable to even hurt them, so eventually they just leave after getting bored.5.RETURNING PLAYERS ARE PUNISHED WITH DELETED CHARACTERS TRAPPED BEHIND A PAYWALL.This is the thing that stung the most for me, when I redownloaded this game and booted it up, I was told to make a new character.That's fine, I don't expect them to keep the data of a guy who hasn't played in who knows how long.Slight problem though....THEY DID HAVE MY DATA, but they wanted me to pay FIFTEEN DOLLARS to recover it.Wow, the most underhanded slimey thing I can think of for a F2P title to do, hold your characters hostage.To massive fans of this game who don't want it to change and who are happy to see it stay exactly how it is, know this.This is a video game, and a business, it will shut down if it keeps this up.The console release of this game could be make or break, so please, let some of the criticism come through.Mark my words, if this game doesn't change it's ways soon, it will go down in under a year.Unless the small number of you who pay to play seriously can keep it afloat, in which case bravo, you're successfully made a game into a buy in club for just you and a select group.These types of games, even this one, tend to only survive based on their non paying, or frequent but not monthly pay players.They keep the community diverse and add to the population, giving you monthly paying customers more people to group and play with, and if the market place wasn't so unaccessible due to the money cap, more people to buy your items in game or sell you something you need.I've slammed down anywhere between 50 and 200 bucks on other games with F2P models, and I don't regret it at all.But this game is making me regret playing it for free.That's a serious problem when you can't even keep cheapskates interested in a "free" product.Bottom line, don't waste your time with this game.The download is rather large if you don't have great internet, and while leveling can be a fun experience once you max out and start thinking about getting sets, working on your character, decorating your hideout, you'll find more roadblocks and annoyances than you would care to stomach.It becomes a pain just trying to manage what little funds you have with what you want, and the game just becomes really unrewarding and punishes you for trying harder with it's money caps and huge gear gaps for late comers.The game pretty much punishes you for getting invested in it, or punishes your wallet if you cave in.There are bad greedy business practices afoot here, and a gaggle of fanboys ready to defend those practices as well.You don't need these problems.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												hmm what to say , this game wa hyped up for about 5 yrs before release at all the  expos ect , showed excellent promise but no one played it was just cut scenes ect , i purchased a box copy of it collectors or something after the closed beta which was impossible to log into to , day 1 they had like 1-200 servers , couldnt connect to any if you did it was for 5 mins then you were booted , after the bombing of the game sony fired 500k staff that helped produce it ect , not sure if it was related to the game or just social order in the company , i stopped playing it for like 3-4 yrs came back and all my stuff was gone , the dlcs costumes ect , started me off from scratch , crap games that get bought and sold a few times never reimburse you for anything , daybreak being one of them , and sony has a 15$ a month all access pass that gives you 500 credits a month btwn all 4 games , none of the games are worth 15$ , this game does have good aspects the movement skills are top notch hanging from walls super speed  flight , they are all a must try , it is a game ported to pc from playstation , so with no controller your kind of screwed , even with a controller you target more oddball♥♥♥♥♥♥then anything barrels ect while dying from bosses or random mobs , the cut scenes are great the 1st time you see them after that its just utterly annoying , the pay to play in a free game is also annoying you either buy stuff at about 10-20$ per purchase or you pay 15$ a month for this game and 3 other♥♥♥♥♥♥games , be advised if you spend 500-2 grand in the store it does nothing you are still a free player you can spend 2grand in money to purchase stuff other then that you have to pay at a minimum of 5$ to withdraw your other "escrow" funds - stuff on ah goes for about 200k in game cash , they added liars but unless you unlock your escrow you are stuck with the small lairs even if you purchase the liars with station cash you still cant go past the 2k lairs so it is still a small place to call your own , there is no customer support at all if you manage to get in touch with them they will put your ticket on hold for a week or 2 then say they couldnt resolve the issue , i got nothing from beta nothing from preorder nothing for buying a box game when it was released , i highly reccomend playing the game just for the travel aspect but other then that dont go near this or anything sony ever comes out with - they remind me of those gas stations that sell gas and dont sell beer or anything so they mark the store goods up 2$ for a can of mnt dew ect - sony shouldve just stuck with sega games  theyre good on 8-16 bit stuff go sonic!!!! lol other then that pure crap

content:
Posted: April 4
												I mainly speak from a nostalgic point of view, I don't have many hours, but I played this game loads on Playstation 3. I've never really been much of an MMO player, I've always found them quite tedious, but when I played this game, it didn't feel this way, yes there are grinding aspects, but I think there's that in a majority of games. Similar to most multiplayer games, it's more fun with friends, so if you have a friend to play it with, make a hero/villian and level together, in my opinion that's the most enjoyable way of playing the game. When you get to max level it doesn't just stop there you can get gear upgrades which include: different weapons and different armors. All the while adjusting your characters appearance to what you think looks good.I haven't played the game in a while but from what I remember, this game was extremely fun, and unique, I would recommend this game to people like MMO's and even people who don't, basically, anyone who can play games, should try this game. I rate it 9/10

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												I have been playing this game on and off through out the years, since its release in 2011 to be exact. A warning of advice, once you get going it is highly addictive and its difficult to stay in touch with the real world. The alure of becoming your own super hero, rescuing civilization in this open world free roam doesn't hold back with literally something to do at every turn. It has never become tiresome. Absolutely one of the best games ever created I can't believe its free!!!! Although, to get the full experince the best way to go is pro and pay your way in with the 20 a month (and quit whenever you want to). It's the best experience you'll have in a video game. 110% worth it, something for everyone!

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												I played DCUO from the very start and took a break.  I recently came back to this game and was pretty much disappointed that I couldn't access my old characters (thanks daybreak!) unless I paid money to get my "deleted" (aka old characters that I never deleted) back. After that, I decided to uninstall.Other than the shady practice, the game is still fun when leveling up, endgame is a pretty tedious grind tbh. Basic powers you start off with are good(fire and ice being near top dps), but if you want more powers you'll have to cough up money, as expected. Biggest question: Can this game keep you for the long run?Nope. For a month or two, sure. I can't see myself playing this again for more than a month.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27
												This game is designed for console players, not for the PC.  DC Universe is a button masher with attack combo's and the keys are as unresponsive as you'd expect.  The awkwardness of youthful growth lends console kids to assume the problem with lack of precision lies in themselves when it is the pathetic coding developed for sheetshow consoles that is the culprit.  In addition, the lack of coordinated targeting as well as command delay serves to be the entirety of the challenge presented by the game.  If the controls were coded for a PC, there would be no game whatsoever and the player base either are OCD enough to endure such frustration sauce or are too young and guillible to know better.  It looks beautiful though and standing on the watchtower looking down on Earth is marvelous.  If you're looking for a Super Hero MMO, Marvel Heroes is fast becoming a third rate D3 clone and another console degenerated pile of suck so the only real PC Super Hero option is still Champions Online of which PWI hardly makes an effort because the competition is all worthless console crap.  Cheers!

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												I personally don't know what people are whining about. The community is great, you see players all over just playing and having fun, granted you don't have a lot of chatterboxes, but I'm not a chatterbox either. I haven't bought anything like membership or whatever yet, but it's very fun as a free game. Yes, you do a lot of running around and sidekick jobs, but so what? It's kinda hard to be "the star of the show" in an MMO where everyone else is also playing. I like flying, but I prefer acrobatics or super speed, the hover disks look cool, but you need to unlock them by buying. I like all the things you can do. you can make nearly any hero you want from Marvel like characters to DC like characters. Like Having Martial Arts, Technology, Acrobatics, and a dark suit..? Who do you have? Batman pretty much. I liked making a deadpool like character too.. that was awesome. Got the black and red, duel sword, comic stance, and some other little things mixed in you can really make a lot of combos.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												I wouldn't say it's a bad MMO. It's a bad *game,* but as far as MMOs go, this is pretty awesome. I wish the quests had some sort of consistent storyline, beyond the short arcs. I wish they'd actually stuck with the "omg Braniac is invading!" arc they were going with in order to explain why villains and heroes could be fighting each other one moment and alongside one another the next. I *really* wish the powers themselves had been free, and that the expansions had been more about in-game content. And, most of all, I wish there were more opportunities to actually interact with the world, rather than just having to behave like a hired thug--it's a little jarring to go through the interesting and complex character creator, only to find yourself in a world that doesn't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about what you do or why you do it at all, beyond the black-and-white "hero or villain?" selection (and obviously there aren't any real ramifications for that action; the voice actors for the villains manage to sound suitably evil, and there are the occasional Kidnap Citizens and Kick Puppies scenes, but otherwise you might as well be punching toasters). Again, by the incredibly lackluster standards MMOs have been setting for themselves, lately (Black Gold, Onigiri, Eden Eternal, I could name a thousand others), this is a very good game. If you enjoy MMOs, you'll enjoy this. I certainly do, for all its flaws. But it disgusts me that I have to qualify it like that.If you're having a hard time enjoying it and are unwilling to give up on it for some reason, try bringing some friends along. Unfortunately, the way quests are set up means that if you chose different mentors you'll be doing different quests at different times, but at least you'll be able to do Raids and Alerts together. And for gods' sake, don't turn PVP on unless you like being followed by higher-leveled players all around the field; they'll wait until you're vulnerable, and then they'll eat you and your delicious experience.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												EDIT: According to another player you can restore your old characters for free, so ignore that.I'm trying to figure out what made me redownload this game, but for the life of me I cannot comprehend what was going through my head.I'll try to be fair and start off this review with things I like about the game.1.Voice acting.The game is almost fully voice acted, and it is done rather well.Some classic voice actors are in this cast, such as mark hamill as the joker, The cutscenes are really nice too, animatic comic shorts with fun dialog.2.CombatThe combat, whilst simplistic at it's core with a rock papper scissors theme with blocking ranged and melee, is rather fun.There are many abilities many weapons and a good ammount of combo's making this feel like a nice action beat uhm up.3.Visually appealing sceneryThe graphics look nice, not 100% modern anymore, but still polished with a few different areas with unique feels between gotham and metropolis.4.Let's you be a hero OR villian.A lot of games now a days have this "nothing is black and white" mentality when it comes to factions.There are usually multiple factions and no one is set in a better light than the other.But in this game you can be outright evil if you want to. (though sadly there is no middle ground or multiple choices, you're either a criminal or a hero)Now onto the reasons why this game is a failure, has failed, and will hopefully shut down.1.Free to play, expensive to enjoy.This game will attempt to squeeze every penny out of you if you let it.Not only are almost half of the power types behind a paywall, there are even basic in game features most mmo games don't even consider making you pay real life money for caged off behind pay walls.One of the worst offenders of this is money in game.That's right, the money you pick up off the ground in game has a limit.1,500$ of in game currency is all you can pick up.If you pick up any more of that without spending it...well, that money is gone now.You can't use it, you can't get to it, but you can look at it taunting you all day just begging you to spend real life cash to get to it.Not a problem you think to yourself, I'll just pay the price of unlocking infinite money an- NO! WRONG!It is a monthly cost to increase your money limit.And it comes in levels.First level?2.5k currency Second,Infinite.So there are two layers of paywalls just to get infinite cash, to use the money you earned to buy things.It's either that or buy tokens to unlock some of the money just once.There are also entire episodes (raids/areas) hidden behind 5 dollar pay walls as well.Just scroll up from this and go look at how much it costs to unlock all of the DLC of this game.Now add up that along with a 15 dollar per month charge just to 'fully' enjoy the game.Fun right?2.Monthly charge option in a F2P game.This is probably the dumbest thing any of these games can do.There is a reason your game couldn't keep using a monthly fee model and survive.It's an outdated archiac payment model.I would almost gladly pay 30 bucks for this game if they removed the money cap and monthly pay option, and just made the things you can buy vanity items.That's how almost 100% of the successful F2P games do it.This game is doomed to shut down just from that, at least till some of the die hard fans start losing their nerve as well.3. Limited to two character slots in F2P.I don't know about you, but a game all about making a unique character should allow you to toy around with more than 2 options.I usually use my second slot for test characters, but everytime I made it to level 10 on one of them, I ended up deleting them because I knew it would be permanent and I couldn't try out any other combinations.So be absolutely sure what you have it what you want, because if you have two characters you don't like, one has to be deleted to make another.4.Huge gear gap.This game has a severe gear gap between new and old school players, and the only way to really fix the gap is to buy some of the newer raids to keep up with the new gear sets.Even tokens in game for buying gear have a currency cap as well, so you will constantly need to go back and forth buying single pieces of gear, going back out and grinding more money, just constantly refreshing your money.I took to buying expensive vendor items and reselling them as currency, which is an painful way to work around the issue of the money cap.I spent a long time trying to grind pvp and money to finally buy a full set of epics in the game.I thought I was pretty well geared, everything I had was a massive upgrade from the blues I had.But along came a plasma glowing shield wielding man, covered head to toe in cash shop effects and a money blocked weapon set.I spent 15 minutes blocking all of his heavy attacks, smashing his ranged attacks, and breaking through his blocks.After all that time I still did no damage to him, and frustrated that he couldn't kill me, he finally just slowly flew away anticlimactically after giving up.There are no words for how depressing that is, to totally outclass someone, but be unable to even hurt them, so eventually they just leave after getting bored.5.RETURNING PLAYERS ARE PUNISHED WITH DELETED CHARACTERS TRAPPED BEHIND A PAYWALL.This is the thing that stung the most for me, when I redownloaded this game and booted it up, I was told to make a new character.That's fine, I don't expect them to keep the data of a guy who hasn't played in who knows how long.Slight problem though....THEY DID HAVE MY DATA, but they wanted me to pay FIFTEEN DOLLARS to recover it.Wow, the most underhanded slimey thing I can think of for a F2P title to do, hold your characters hostage.To massive fans of this game who don't want it to change and who are happy to see it stay exactly how it is, know this.This is a video game, and a business, it will shut down if it keeps this up.The console release of this game could be make or break, so please, let some of the criticism come through.Mark my words, if this game doesn't change it's ways soon, it will go down in under a year.Unless the small number of you who pay to play seriously can keep it afloat, in which case bravo, you're successfully made a game into a buy in club for just you and a select group.These types of games, even this one, tend to only survive based on their non paying, or frequent but not monthly pay players.They keep the community diverse and add to the population, giving you monthly paying customers more people to group and play with, and if the market place wasn't so unaccessible due to the money cap, more people to buy your items in game or sell you something you need.I've slammed down anywhere between 50 and 200 bucks on other games with F2P models, and I don't regret it at all.But this game is making me regret playing it for free.That's a serious problem when you can't even keep cheapskates interested in a "free" product.Bottom line, don't waste your time with this game.The download is rather large if you don't have great internet, and while leveling can be a fun experience once you max out and start thinking about getting sets, working on your character, decorating your hideout, you'll find more roadblocks and annoyances than you would care to stomach.It becomes a pain just trying to manage what little funds you have with what you want, and the game just becomes really unrewarding and punishes you for trying harder with it's money caps and huge gear gaps for late comers.The game pretty much punishes you for getting invested in it, or punishes your wallet if you cave in.There are bad greedy business practices afoot here, and a gaggle of fanboys ready to defend those practices as well.You don't need these problems.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Awesome game. I usually don't play many mmo's but this one was addictive. Awesome graphics and handling. Controls are incredibly fluid, more fluid then a lot of action games. One nice feature, that I've never seen in an MMORPG, is the focus on making a world feel large and immersive by making the world large vertically. You can climb up large skyscrapers and jump down from them or fly around the cities. After the level cap at 30, it can get repetitive, so you'll want to find a league to keep you company. You can also just create another character with a different role, ability, and/or mentor and play through the main game again. It has a decent amount of customization options and collectibles to find. There's a lot to do in this game.

content:
Posted: February 27
												This game is designed for console players, not for the PC.  DC Universe is a button masher with attack combo's and the keys are as unresponsive as you'd expect.  The awkwardness of youthful growth lends console kids to assume the problem with lack of precision lies in themselves when it is the pathetic coding developed for sheetshow consoles that is the culprit.  In addition, the lack of coordinated targeting as well as command delay serves to be the entirety of the challenge presented by the game.  If the controls were coded for a PC, there would be no game whatsoever and the player base either are OCD enough to endure such frustration sauce or are too young and guillible to know better.  It looks beautiful though and standing on the watchtower looking down on Earth is marvelous.  If you're looking for a Super Hero MMO, Marvel Heroes is fast becoming a third rate D3 clone and another console degenerated pile of suck so the only real PC Super Hero option is still Champions Online of which PWI hardly makes an effort because the competition is all worthless console crap.  Cheers!

content:
Posted: February 18, 2012
												For the first 20 levels, this is rather good for free. For anyone interested in comic books and designing your own would be hero or villian, it's definetly worth a go. Like a sunday afternoon movie rental, it may be no masterpiece or hold any  long term interest, but it's certainly worth a viewing. It just starts to get a bit lonely in this slightly vacant MMO. "Looking for Group" is non existent and unless PvP is your thing, then the only option are a few group events. Grinding is minimal or doesn't seem too bad anyway, and the speed at which you level and get new powers keeps you dipping your toe in. This would be good with a few mates, bashing a way round Gotham and Metropolis, but playing solo for the shortterm is fine but seems to be more of an unpolished button basing action adventure. Would I reccommend it? Yes, but doubt there is long term appeal...but in an MMO that's not a bad thing :-)

content:
Posted: April 19, 2016
												Played this a while ago and got to level 15 or something....It sucks as a free player because most of the powers were unavailable without paying and you were really restricted quickly. The story was too short to be considered complete and more of that would have been nice.PvP sucked: I enjoyed getting one-shot in TERA multiple times by a troll more than I enjoyed the two or three times I entered PvP in this game and actually had a chance of surviving.The combat and movement mechanics were fun, but there weren't many creative ways to use them. I feel bad for any players who picked the speedforce... actually any super power as their superpower.Never got into the gear much: I couldn't come to care all that much because it felt like it came from the Walmart for superheroes. Great for civilian living but useless if you really want to define yourself with that unique designer look that screams "quality".I wish it had a more unique story and more involved character development. It's interesting but I don't feel invested in my hero.Not worth paying for since the game itself needs a lot of work.It's like they took a potentially amazing game and: Alpha tested it when it was half finished; Fixed the bugs of that; Went to beta; Fixed more bugs; And realeased it as an... okay game. Then they tried to fix lategame shortcomings (lack of actual content) by throwing higher numbers at it without giving a any meaning to it.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
Product received for free
												Patience. Patience is the key word. It's PvP is amazingly fun with the right friends... when it's actually working properly and is balanced, which is extremely hard and an extremely long wait. If you can do that, it will be worth it.Why the long wait? Ever since it's license was renewed, DCUO developers have had to pump out PvE content every month, leaving little room for PvP. It was updated in January 2016, but it has not been updated since then, but it's a start. As you can tell, PvP is my shtick, as for PvE, it's not bad, but from what I've heard from launch players, it's been better.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												I was really excited to try out another 'super-hero' MMO. DC Universe seemed like a good choice, mostly thanks to official DC characters and locations. I've played some Champions Online much earlier, and you know what? I think, that even with all of those micro-transactions Champions Online is still a better choice. First off, at DCU you will start from creating the character. But unfortunately you don't have much options, body type, skin type, abilities and clothes - which totally doesn't matter, 'cause your character will use other clothes or armor most of the time.At the end you have to choose 3 main colors of your superhero. Exactly 3. Sounds poorly? Yes it does.Graphically DCU is horrible. It tends to have some low textured places, but the main defect is really awful graphical style. Uninteresting opponents, uninteresting heroes... Thankfully audio is much better than the graphic. The music isn't irritating, and it has it's moments. Of course, for some of us it may pall. Some of abilities are fun, some are not, half of them has ridiculous graphic effects, like from Heroes of Might and Magic IV. Seriously, shooting the enemy with white, spiky ball by clapping your hands (skill: brawling)? C'mon.Leveling your char may be fun, for some time. I got bored after a while, uninteresting locations didn't help. But you should check out some gameplays of the game, just in case.To try the end game stuff you have to pay for some DLC - otherwise, it ain't got much sense. I think, that Champions Online, with all of it's drawbacks is still more fun to play than DC Universe. I didn't like DCU, I don't recommend it.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												The trailer is cool, really makes you want to play this game.It is probably the best comics superhero simulator around, and you can customize your character the way you want within the limits of the free account. But the progression is boring, the missions are quite repetitive. The fight style is interesting in theory, you can do so many things, but you have to lock your targets all the time or just fight aimlessly, also it doesn't seem right to move the screen with the mouse during a fight, i mean, the mouse isn't free to use, it only moves the screen view, but oh well it's a different style, not really a problem. It feels like you are supposed to play this game with a controller for a better experience.There's the oracle that will teach you the basics, there's your mentor as well who will give you missions which you can complete just by pressing J, you don't have to meet them all the time. After I completed the first tutorial and was finally level 3 i had to take a break, I just couldn't stand the fight style anymore. But then I gave a second try, went on some missions, killing repeatedly the same kind of creatures, talking to npcs, standard MMO routine, kill 10 of these, 10 of those, 15 of those, now 15 of the other ones... meh.I havent't played much, but anyone can see this game has a huge map, and it may be cool to explore it, flying or using your superspeed. Voice acting is good. Has nice graphics, which helps explain the disk usage of the whole thing (18gb+4gb after installing it). Perhaps it gets more interesting later on, but I wasn't thrilled with the fighting mechanics in the first place, also got quickly bored with the missions.It's a F2P MMO, but definitely has P2W mechanics, though it's nothing that will bother your beginning phase in this game. In general, however, it's quite a discouraging feature.Another sad thing is when the server is "undergoing a scheduled maintenance" and you attempt to login, but the message you receive is that your "name or password is invalid, please try again", which makes you think you mistyped something or forgot your pw... recheck, retype or even try and change your pw, but as the site will be down you'll finally realize the server is actually down and there's nothing wrong with your ID. They could just inform that 'the server is down' or they're 'having technical difficulties'.This game should be good, but I didn't like it, though you should definitely give it a try if you have no problem with what I mentioned above... have fun.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												A fantastic free-to-play action MMO with diverse character customization options which unlock throughout a short, but fun leveling experience. Endgame content, including PVP, is DLC-gated, as are some character creation options. A monthly subscription fee provides access to these features without needing to purchase individual content packs. Endgame progression is heavily dominated by the use of 'replay tokens,' items purchased through microtransactions to reset daily and weekly instance lockouts on loot. Without these, character progression at level cap is slow and arduous. Endgame performance also relies heavily on regular play to maintain buffs and amenities which have associated monthly fees of in-game currency, which inherently punishes you for any appreciable length of time spent away from the game.All-in-all, a fun, exciting free-to-play game which falls short of being fully engaging at level cap due to a combination of either subscription fees/DLC purchases, microtransactional-dependent raid farming, and grinding of excess unwanted in-game currency to pay monthly upkeep costs for buffs and gear.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												I've played this game quite a lot and OMG, I really wish I hadn't. Firstly, the character creation process is terrible. Everything is where it shouldn't be and you're likely to end up looking very derpy. The game claims to use "action combat", which is RaiderZ style combat; you have to actually hit the enemy. DCUO does not use any real type of action combat, it's just target your enemy and you'll never miss while button mashing every power. Some enemies are also rather buggy (mainly the HIVE ironically) and don't seem to be taking damage.As far is gameplay goes, it's just grinding... all the time, non-stop. You gain barely any experience from killing enemies so your only real source of levelling are the awful quests that are generally given to you by your mentor who clearly can't do things themselves. The questing is something akin to that of games made by Perfect World: Kill several monsters; collect their stuff; go gathering stuff; repeat; raid copy-pasted dungeon.The download for this game is a nightmare, the Steam download is 20gb! Then you also have to start the game and let it re-install on the "Station". I had to leave my laptop on over-night just to download this game.The game may be free-to-play, but it is definately pay-to-win. Most powers are DLC only and if you want cool stuff, you'll need to use the cash-shop or subcribe and pay monthly. Despite all this, if you were playing with friends as I was, you will probably have a bit more fun.3/10 Would not play again.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												Great game! Before I go into my review, I must first make it clear that the game is not really a Free to Play. I say this because after you hit level 30, you hit subscription-based paywall. With that said, though, the features players pay for are totally worth it in that you get hours upon hours upon hours of fun (I have over 1000 hours in the game...). Pros About the Game:- Unique MMORPG (superheroes man, how much better can it get?)- Insane customization- Decent character creation- Game community and Daybreak (game company) communicate well and creators listen to players.- Monthly DLC is gone and now replaced with larger DLC packs being released every few months.Cons About the Game:- "Free to Play" is almost false considering the pay-to-win structure of the game (ie: Utility Belt)- Missions are fun, but get pretty boring- Not really much replay value with regards to low level operationsAll in all, I really enjoy this game; I wouldn't have played over a thousand hours of it if I didn't. That said, the game is really meant to be for those who are ready to pay for DLC or subscribe to a membership. If you can't afford to do so, for whatever reason, you may want to re-consider hopping into this game. If you can afford it however, then I highly recommend you give the game a try; I mean it’s free until level 30 anyways so there’s nothing to loose and everything to gain!

For fans of MMORPGs, Comic books and Free games, this is definitely a game for you!9/10

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												It's a great game, very interesting. It's like my version of world of warcraft (which I've never played(Sorry) You can make either a hero or villain and customize their powers, weapons, and movement style. THough alot of powers are dlc they do come with other extra content (but let's face it, you'd only get it for the powers) You can even make pre-existing characters from the dc universe Like Terry in the Batman Beyond suit. Heck even Marvel characters can be made. Being a villain is fun and can also be extreme at times. My villain is a scoundrel named Qwailman (he's like the penguin but got the whole Quail element instead) who runs around shooting hand cannons and pigeon bombing cars. He also runs around yelling, "Indubitebleh!" Though he can't even compare with "The Knitter" (http://lolsnaps.com/funny/45421) But he's getting there. I highly reccommend this game, especially if you like superheroes (Don't get me started on my Japanese Tv show....). However there is room for improvement so I give it 9 toasties out of 10 toasties.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												This game is fun and easy to play. Its not like you're basic mmo games which get repetitive again and again... I have pros and cons about this game and one of the bad things about this game is that the level limit is too low in my opinion. The level limit is lvl 30 BUT once you reach lvl 30 you can do dungeon missions which give u amazing gear and increases your combat rating so you can unlock more levels. This game has a safehouse so you can decorate. Plenty of dungeons and events. The story line is amazing but unfortunately short. Another thing bad about this game is character slots. It allows you to create only 2 players i would like 4 or 5 but okay... You can become a hero or villian each side changes your storyline of your mentor of going to Metropolis first or Gotham first. This game has crafting and PVP and PVE servers if you want to play. The character customization is cool and unique. You can join and create guilds along the way... There are random bosses in different areas such as in Metropolis or in Gotham. You can have mentors such as Batman, Superman, Superwoman, The Joker, Lex Luthor, and Circe. Picking different mentors change the storyline like i said but it doesnt change it too much...

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												So the game is set in a universe where Braniac shows up and everyones like "Oh noes we need to stop him1!1!1!111!!!" while villains and heroes still fight eachother. Thats fine. Moral reasonings, character personas, unite under a common enemy, blah blah blah. Keep in mind that Braniac is the main bad guy and you need to stop him, hero or villain.So apparently from what Im seeing, you dont actually get to fight braniac himself. You just do stuff. If you want to fight him you nedd to- what? PURCHASE DLC TO DO WHAT THE GAME IS ADVERTISING YOU TO DO?!?!?!I do not have confirmation that this is false, but if I do get it this review will go down immediately. But for now this is unacceptable. Its like playing through a mario game, and then you had to pay to fight bowser. Disgusting.TL;DR : Game says you have to fight Big bad final boss. Only way to get to big bad final boss is DLC.And I thought EA was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Game itself is fun and all, but this is downright sickeningGame: 7/10 DLC: Automatic 0/10

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												This is a bad game. Cons Horrific lipsync.Quests are mostly if not all "Defeat 10 Thugs" and/or "Try turning off a thing that takes several seconds, but this process stops when one if the infinitely spawning enemies hits you."Weightless actions. Literally nothing changes when you complete a quest.Poorly designed PVP.Combat is unsatisfying and enemies have no reaction to being attacked. They don't even flinch.Limited amount of in game currency. If you exceed this amount it is put into escrow and you can only access it by paying real money.PVP and PVE gear are both dropped from regular gameplay. PVP gear gets disabled if you do an Alert/Raid. Pros Living out your fantasy of being a hero/villain.Standing on tall buildings while your cape flutters.You can override the appearance of any of your gear.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												This game was fun until lvl 30..then its just a pointless grind for gear with really repetative raids and a very limited combat system (pretty much paper, rock scissors except its block, punch & hard hit). Not to mention the game is pay to win once you hit lvl 30 and want to be at ALL competative. They make you pay for extra power sets, and extra weapon sets, also extra content, dungeons, and even to hold more cash in your bank (seriously? I cant even earn more money through hard ingame work without opening my wallet? :/)Once you realize how little there is to do thats fun post lvl 30, you start to feel like your time invested lvling up was wasted, and thats the part that really sucks about this game. if the combat system & end game content were better then this game would be fun..but for right now, its a WASTE OF TIME.
